original_data.question:
A 3-day-old male is evaluated in the hospital nursery for delayed passage of meconium. His mother is breastfeeding and has started to produce milk. The patient has been feeding well every two hours and is urinating over eight times per day. The patient was born at 35 weeks gestation to a 27-year-old gravida 4. The patient is of Ashkenazi Jewish descent, and the patient’s parents denied all prenatal genetic testing. The pregnancy was uncomplicated until the patient’s mother had spontaneous rupture of membranes at 35 weeks gestation. The patient’s three older siblings are all healthy. In the hospital nursery, the patient’s temperature is 98.2°F (36.8°C), blood pressure is 48/32 mmHg, pulse is 164/min, and respirations are 48/min. On physical exam, he appears to be in moderate distress. He has no dysmorphic features, and his abdomen is distended and non-tender. Bowel sounds are absent.

Which of the following is the best next step in management?

model_response:
The patient’s clinical presentation is consistent with neonatal intestinal obstruction. The differential diagnosis includes duodenal atresia, jejunal atresia, ileal atresia, meconium plug syndrome, meconium ileus, and Hirschsprung’s disease. The next best step in management is to obtain an abdominal radiograph. The contrast enema and upper gastrointestinal series are both invasive and may delay definitive treatment. Hirschsprung’s disease is a consideration given the patient’s age and the absence of stool passage. However, the patient’s clinical presentation is more consistent with a mechanical obstruction. Sweat testing is used to diagnose cystic fibrosis, which is a consideration given the patient’s Ashkenazi Jewish descent. However, the patient’s clinical presentation is more consistent with a mechanical obstruction.

Answer: OPTION A IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: A person who belongs to the sex that normally produces sperm. The term is used to indicate biological sex distinctions, cultural gender role distinctions, or both.
Institutions with an organized medical staff which provide medical care to patients.
Hold back to a later time.

The thick green-to-black mucilaginous material found in the intestines of a full-term fetus. It consists of secretions of the INTESTINAL GLANDS; BILE PIGMENTS; FATTY ACIDS; AMNIOTIC FLUID; and intrauterine debris. It constitutes the first stools passed by a newborn.
Female parents, human or animal.
The nursing of an infant at the breast.
The off-white liquid secreted by the mammary glands of humans and other mammals. It contains proteins, sugar, lipids, vitamins, and minerals.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
A unit measure of time equal to 3,600 seconds or 60 minutes. It is approximately 1/24 of a median day.
Occurring or done each day.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
The event of being born.
Any period of seven consecutive days.
The status during which female mammals carry their developing young (EMBRYOS or FETUSES) in utero before birth, beginning from FERTILIZATION to BIRTH.
The number of pregnancies, complete or incomplete, experienced by a female. It is different from PARITY, which is the number of offspring borne. (From Stedman, 26th ed)
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
Persons functioning as natural, adoptive, or substitute parents. The heading includes the concept of parenthood as well as preparation for becoming a parent.
Analyzing DNA to look for a genetic alteration that may indicate an increased risk for developing a cancer.
The status during which female mammals carry their developing young (EMBRYOS or FETUSES) in utero before birth, beginning from FERTILIZATION to BIRTH.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
Female parents, human or animal.
Tear or break of an organ, vessel or other soft part of the body, occurring in the absence of external force.
Thin layers of tissue which cover parts of the body, separate adjacent cavities, or connect adjacent structures.
Any period of seven consecutive days.
The status during which female mammals carry their developing young (EMBRYOS or FETUSES) in utero before birth, beginning from FERTILIZATION to BIRTH.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
Persons or animals having at least one parent in common. (American College Dictionary, 3d ed)
Having no significant health-related issues.
Institutions with an organized medical staff which provide medical care to patients.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
The measure of the level of heat of a human or animal.
PRESSURE of the BLOOD on the ARTERIES and other BLOOD VESSELS.
A non-SI unit of pressure equal to 133,332 Pa or 1.316E10-3 standard atmosphere. Use of this unit is generally deprecated by ISO and IUPAC.
The rhythmical expansion and contraction of an ARTERY produced by waves of pressure caused by the ejection of BLOOD from the left ventricle of the HEART as it contracts.

The act of breathing with the LUNGS, consisting of INHALATION, or the taking into the lungs of the ambient air, and of EXHALATION, or the expelling of the modified air which contains more CARBON DIOXIDE than the air taken in (Blakiston's Gould Medical Dictionary, 4th ed.). This does not include tissue respiration (= OXYGEN CONSUMPTION) or cell respiration (= CELL RESPIRATION).
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.
A state of physiological or psychological stress that cannot be compensated for by normal adaptive measures.
That portion of the body that lies between the THORAX and the PELVIS.
Not existing in a specified place at a specified time.
Performing or possessing executive duties; acting as a supervisor or manager.
